title: My 50/50 partner has locked me out of the store, changed banking info and thinks she can just change the name of the store -
question: What are my rights as a partner going on a verbal agreement, no contract? Also, our names are on most everything showing us a partner except for the resale license, which is under me. I did want a buy out but now with the dishonesty, I want out completely and the store shut down, what are my legal rights on doing that? How can you just rename a business and start over without me knowing or the right legal documents filed to dissolve the partnership? I am so confused and need help!!
answers:
You need to consult with a corporate litigation attorney to assist you in protecting your "rights". Unfortunately, it will be more complex because of your having failed to enter into a written agreement, and your using a 'partnership' rather than a corporation or LLC.

The time to protect your "rights" is before, rather than after, there is trouble. At this point it will not be clear what your "rights" are, since you never tried to protect them before.

You have referred several times to your “partner” and the “partnership,” but you filed the post under LLC. Which is it? The difference matters in determining your rights and remedies. If you have “no contract,” does that mean you have not filed Articles for an LLC? I will assume that it is a partnership, so you are relying on the CA statute as to partnership rights. Messrs Doland and Hanson have some useful and erudite suggestions. I agree generally with both of them. However, it sounds like she is not about to settle. You need to decide how much the business is worth and whether it is worth investing in hiring a business lawyer to help you recover what she owes you, which is half of everything, plus possibly punitive damages for breach of her fiduciary duties to you.

Do I need to tell you it was a mistake not to get a written, signed Operating Agreement when you were getting along? Such an agreement could spell out the answers to a lot of your questions.

You two owe each other what are called fiduciary duties. Big legal names for "play nice." Neither one of you have the right to take advantage of the other to benefit yourself.

Way back in 1928, a famous Judge in New York, Benjamin N. Cardozo, in an opinion known as Meinhard v. Salmon, 164 N.E. 545 (1928) said, "Joint adventurers, like copartners, owe to one another, while the enterprise continues, the duty of the finest loyalty. Many forms of conduct permissible in a workaday world for those acting at arm's length, are forbidden to those bound by fiduciary ties. A trustee is held to something stricter than the morals of the market place. Not honesty alone, but the punctilio of an honor the most sensitive, is then the standard of behavior."

So, of course, your partner had no right to do what she did. And you are probably going to have to hire an experienced business lawyer, and sue to undo what has been done. You know who is going to win that suit? The lawyers. If you can find any way to avoid going to court, and just work something out with your partner, you will both be miles ahead.

One approach which sometimes works, is what I call a simultaneous offer. I wrote an article on this subject in the Illinois Bar Journal for June, 2007, Volume 95 • Number 6 • Page 328. Essentially this is like a mother allowing one child to cut the pie, and then allowing another child first choice of which piece she wishes.

Go to your partner and make an offer, setting forth your estimation of the value of the whole company. Be as detailed as you can as to not only the price, but all other terms: Cash or installments? Interest rate? Security for the unpaid portion? Term over which payments will be made? Will the seller agree not to compete with the business for a period of time? Will the seller resign from all positions in the company? Are there personally guaranteed debts of the business, and if so, will the buyer get the seller released? Or agree to indemnify her? Etc.

Indicate to your partner that this is your best estimate of a fair deal, and you will be willing to either (1) buy her out on these terms, or (2) have her buy you out on the same terms.

Making a simultaneous offer in no way compels her to either buy or sell. If it doesn't work, however, I believe you will be in a stronger position to convince a judge, or a jury, as to the reasonableness of your price and terms because you were willing to take either side of the deal.

Sometimes this works. I wish you the best of luck.

Both Jesus and Abraham Lincoln encouraged people to settle their disputes as quickly as possible. Why? Because its the best way. I hope you can do it, and that's going to involve convincing your partner to do it, too.

The state of California imposes a partnership agreement by statute on any two or more persons doing business together. It is located in the California Corporations code. To enforce your rights you will have to go to court, although you might consider giving one chance to your "partner" to go to mediation to try to fashion a "win-win" as opposed to a "win-lose" which is litigation. Trying to involuntarily dissolve a statutory partnership (and sue for breach of fiduciary duty) would almost certainly benefit from an attorney, at least to prepare the complaint if not assist you thereafter on the way to trial. Some lawyers offer "unbundled" legal services and sell certain legal "products" without becoming your attorney of record. Otherwise, go to your county law library and look for California Forms of Pleading and Practice. Final hint, 200 hundred consecutive questions on Avvo won't be the same as having an attorney.
